books.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 1

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 1:1
verses.text: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II: Chapter I.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 1:2
verses.text: Happiness in life is to be gained by living virtuously, inasmuch as thus a Christian, whilst despising glory and the favour of men, desires to please God alone in what he does.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 1:3
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 1:4
verses.text: In the first book we spoke of the duties which we thought befitted a virtuous life, whereon no one has ever doubted but that a blessed life, which the Scripture calls eternal life, depends.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 1:5
verses.text: So great is the splendour of a virtuous life that a peaceful conscience and a calm innocence work out a happy life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 1:6
verses.text: And as the risen sun hides the globe of the moon and the light of the stars, so the brightness of a virtuous life, where it glitters in true pure glory, casts into the shade all other things, which, according to the desires of the body, are considered to be good, or are reckoned in the eyes of the world to be great and noble.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 1:7
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 1:8
verses.text: Blessed, plainly, is that life which is not valued at the estimation of outsiders, but is known, as judge of itself, by its own inner feelings.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 1:9
verses.text: It needs no popular opinion as its reward in any way; nor has it any fear of punishments.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 1:10
verses.text: Thus the less it strives for glory, the more it rises above it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 1:11
verses.text: For to those who seek for glory, that reward in the shape of present things is but a shadow of future ones, and is a hindrance to eternal life, as it is written in the Scriptures: "Verily, I say unto you, they have received their reward".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 1:12
verses.text: This is said of those who, as it were, with the sound of a trumpet desire to make known to all the world the liberality they exercise towards the poor.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 1:13
verses.text: It is the same, too, in the case of fasting,  which is done but for outward show.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 1:14
verses.text: "They have," he says, "their reward".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 1:15
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 1:16
verses.text: It therefore belongs to a virtuous life to show mercy and to fast in secret; that thou mayest seem to be seeking a reward from thy God alone, and not from men.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 1:17
verses.text: For he who seeks it from man has his reward, but he who seeks it from God has eternal life, which none can give but the Lord of Eternity, as it is said: "Verily, I say unto thee, to-day shalt thou be with Me in Paradise".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 1:18
verses.text: Wherefore the Scripture plainly has called that life which is blessed, eternal life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 1:19
verses.text: It has not been left to be appraised according to man's ideas on the subject, but has been entrusted to the divine judgment.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 2

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 2:1
verses.text: Chapter II.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 2:2
verses.text: The different ideas of philosophers on the subject of happiness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 2:3
verses.text: He proves, first, from the Gospel that it rests on the knowledge of God and the pursuit of good works; next, that it may not be thought that this idea was adopted from the philosophers, he adds proofs from the witness of the prophets.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 2:4
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 2:5
verses.text: The philosophers have made a happy life to depend, either (as Hieronymus) on freedom from pain, or (as Herillus) on knowledge.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 2:6
verses.text: For Herillus, hearing knowledge very highly praised by Aristotle and Theophrastus, made it alone to be the chief good, when they really praised it as a good thing, not as the only good; others, as Epicurus, have called pleasure such; others, as Callipho, and after him Diodorus, understood it in such a way as to make a virtuous life go in union, the one with pleasure, the other with freedom from pain, since a happy life could not exist without it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 2:7
verses.text: Zeno, the Stoic, thought the highest and only good existed in a virtuous life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 2:8
verses.text: But Aristotle and Theophrastus and the other Peripatetics maintained that a happy life consisted in virtue, that is, in a virtuous life, but that its happiness was made complete by the advantages of the body and other external good things.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 2:9
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 2:10
verses.text: But the sacred Scriptures say that eternal life rests on a knowledge of divine things and on the fruit of good works.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 2:11
verses.text: The Gospel bears witness to both these statements.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 2:12
verses.text: For the Lord Jesus spoke thus of knowledge: "This is eternal life, to know Thee, the only true God, and Jesus Christ Whom Thou hast sent".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 2:13
verses.text: About works He gives this answer: "Every one that hath forsaken house, or brethren, or sisters, or father, or mother, or wife, or children, or lands, for My Name's sake, shall receive an hundred-fold, and shall inherit everlasting life".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 2:14
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 2:15
verses.text: Let no one think that this was but lately said, and that it was spoken of by the philosophers before it was mentioned in the Gospel.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 2:16
verses.text: For the philosophers, that is to say, Aristotle and Theophrastus, as also Zeno and Hieronymus, certainly lived before the time of the Gospel; but they came after the prophets.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 2:17
verses.text: Let them rather think how long before even the names of the philosophers were heard of, both of these seem to have found open expression through the mouth of the holy David; for it is written: "Blessed is the man whom Thou instructest, O Lord, and teachest him out of Thy law".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 2:18
verses.text: We find elsewhere also: "Blessed is the man that feareth the Lord, he will rejoice greatly in His commandments".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 2:19
verses.text: We have proved our point as regards knowledge, the reward for which the prophet states to be the fruit of eternity, adding that in the house of the man that feareth the Lord, or is instructed in His law and rejoices greatly in the divine commandments, "is glory and riches; and his justice abideth for ever and ever".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 2:20
verses.text: He has further also in the same psalm stated of good works, that they gain for an upright man the gift of eternal life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 2:21
verses.text: He speaks thus: "Blessed is the man that showeth pity and lendeth, he will guide his affairs with discretion, surely he shall not be moved for ever, the righteous shall be in everlasting remembrance".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 2:22
verses.text: And further: "He hath dispersed, he hath given to the poor, his justice endureth for ever".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 2:23
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 2:24
verses.text: Faith, then, has [the promise of] eternal life, for it is a good foundation.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 2:25
verses.text: Good works, too, have the same, for an upright man is tested by his words and acts.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 2:26
verses.text: For  if a man is always busy talking and yet is slow to act, he shows by his acts how worthless his knowledge is: besides it is much worse to know what one ought to do, and yet not to do what one has learnt should be done.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 2:27
verses.text: On the other hand, to be active in good works and unfaithful at heart is as idle as though one wanted to raise a beautiful and lofty dome upon a bad foundation.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 2:28
verses.text: The higher one builds, the greater is the fall; for without the protection of faith good works cannot stand.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 2:29
verses.text: A treacherous anchorage in a harbour perforates a ship, and a sandy bottom quickly gives way and cannot bear the weight of the building placed upon it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 2:30
verses.text: There then will be found the fulness of reward, where the virtues are perfect, and where there is a reasonable agreement between words and acts.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 3

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 3:1
verses.text: Chapter III.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 3:2
verses.text: The definition of blessedness as drawn from the Scriptures is considered and proved.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 3:3
verses.text: It cannot be enhanced by external good fortune, nor can it be weakened by misfortune.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 3:4
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 3:5
verses.text: As, then, knowledge, so far as it stands alone, is put aside either as worthless, according to the superfluous discussions of the philosophers, or as but an imperfect idea, let us now note how clearly the divine Scriptures explain a thing about which we see the philosophers held so many involved and perplexing ideas.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 3:6
verses.text: For the Scriptures state that nothing is good but what is virtuous, and declare that virtue is blessed in every circumstance, and that it is never enhanced by either corporal or other external good fortune, nor is it weakened by adversity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 3:7
verses.text: No state is so blessed as that wherein one is free from sin, is filled with innocence, and is fully supplied with the grace of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 3:8
verses.text: For it is written: "Blessed is the man that hath not walked in the counsel of the ungodly, and hath not stood in the way of sinners, and hath not sat in the seat of pestilence, but in the law of the Lord was his delight".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 3:9
verses.text: And again: "Blessed are the undefiled in the way, who walk in the law of the Lord".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 3:10
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 3:11
verses.text: Innocence, then, and knowledge make a man blessed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 3:12
verses.text: We have also noted already that the blessedness of eternal life is the reward for good works.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 3:13
verses.text: It remains, then, to show that when the patronage of pleasure or the fear of pain is despised (and the first of these one abhors as poor and effeminate, and the other as unmanly and weak), that then a blessed life can rise up in the midst of pain.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 3:14
verses.text: This can easily be shown when we read: "Blessed are ye when men shall revile you and persecute you and shall say all manner of evil against you for righteousness' sake.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 3:15
verses.text: Rejoice and be exceeding glad, for great is your reward in heaven; for so persecuted they the prophets which were before you".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 3:16
verses.text: And again: "He that will come after Me, let him take up his cross and follow Me".

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 4

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 4:1
verses.text: Chapter IV.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 4:2
verses.text: The same argument, namely, that blessedness is not lessened or added to by external matters, is illustrated by the example of men of old.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 4:3
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 4:4
verses.text: There is, then, a blessedness even in pains and griefs.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 4:5
verses.text: All which virtue with its sweetness checks and restrains, abounding as it does in natural resources for either soothing conscience or increasing grace.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 4:6
verses.text: For Moses was blessed in no small degree when, surrounded by the Egyptians and shut in by the sea, he found by his merits a way for himself and the people to go through the waters.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 4:7
verses.text: When was he ever braver than at the moment when, surrounded by the greatest dangers, he gave not up the hope of safety, but besought a triumph?  11.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 4:8
verses.text: What of Aaron? When did he ever think himself more blessed than when he stood between the living and the dead, and by his presence stayed death from passing from the bodies of the dead to the lines of the living? What shall I say of the youth Daniel, who was so wise that, when in the midst of the lions enraged with hunger, he was by no means overcome with terror at the fierceness of the beasts.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 4:9
verses.text: So free from fear was he, that he could eat, and was not afraid he might by his example excite the animals to feed on him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 4:10
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 4:11
verses.text: There is, then, in pain a virtue that can display the sweetness of a good conscience, and therefore it serves as a proof that pain does not lessen the pleasure of virtue.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 4:12
verses.text: As, then, there is no loss of blessedness to virtue through pain, so also the pleasures of the body and the enjoyment that benefits give add nothing to it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 4:13
verses.text: On this the Apostle says well: "What things to me were gain, those I counted loss for Christ," and he added: "Wherefore I count all things but loss, and do count them but dung, that I may win Christ".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 4:14
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 4:15
verses.text: Moses, too, thought the treasures of Egypt to be his loss, and thus showed forth in his life the reproach of the Cross of the Lord.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 4:16
verses.text: He was not rich when he had abundance of money, nor was he afterwards poor when he was in want of food, unless, perchance, there is any one who thinks he was less happy when daily food was wanting to him and his people in the wilderness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 4:17
verses.text: But yet manna, that is, angels' food, which surely none will dare deny to be a mark of the greatest good and of blessedness, was given him from heaven; also the daily shower of meat was sufficient to feed the whole multitude.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 4:18
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 4:19
verses.text: Bread for food also failed Elijah, that holy man, had he sought for it; but it seemed not to fail him because he sought it not.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 4:20
verses.text: Thus by the daily service of the ravens bread was brought to him in the morning, meat in the evening.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 4:21
verses.text: Was he any the less blessed because he was poor to himself? Certainly not.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 4:22
verses.text: Nay, he was the more blessed, for he was rich toward God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 4:23
verses.text: It is better to be rich for others than for oneself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 4:24
verses.text: He was so, for in the time of famine he asked a widow for food, intending to repay it, so that the barrel of meal failed not for three years and six months, and the oil jar sufficed and served the needy widow for her daily use all that time also.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 4:25
verses.text: Rightly did Peter wish to be there where he saw them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 4:26
verses.text: Rightly did they appear in the mount with Christ in glory, for He Himself became poor when He was rich.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 4:27
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 4:28
verses.text: Riches, then, give no assistance to living a blessed life, a fact that the Lord clearly shows in the Gospel, saying: "Blessed are ye poor, for yours is the kingdom of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 4:29
verses.text: Blessed are they that hunger and thirst now, for they shall be filled.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 4:30
verses.text: Blessed are ye that weep now, for ye shall laugh".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 4:31
verses.text: Thus it is stated as plainly as possible that poverty, hunger, and pain, which are considered to be evils, not only are not hindrances to a blessed life, but are actually so many helps toward it.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 5

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 5:1
verses.text: Chapter V.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 5:2
verses.text: Those things which are generally looked on as good are mostly hindrances to a blessed life, and those which are looked on as evil are the materials out of which virtues grow.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 5:3
verses.text: What belongs to blessedness is shown by other examples.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 5:4
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 5:5
verses.text: But those things which seem to be good, as riches, abundance, joy without pain, are a hindrance to the fruits of blessedness, as is clearly stated in the Lord's own words, when He said: "Woe to you rich, for ye have received your consolation! Woe unto you that are full, for ye shall hunger, and to those who laugh, for they shall mourn!" So, then, corporal or external good things are not only no assistance to attaining a blessed life, but are even a hindrance to it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 5:6
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 5:7
verses.text: Wherefore Naboth was blessed, even though he was stoned by the rich; weak and poor, as opposed to the royal resources, he was rich in his aim and his religion; so rich, indeed, that he would not exchange the inheritance of the vineyard received from his father for the king's money; and on this account was he perfect, for he defended the rights of his forefathers with his own blood.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 5:8
verses.text: Thus, also, Ahab was wretched on his own showing, for he caused the poor man to be put to death, so as to take possession of his vineyard himself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 5:9
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 5:10
verses.text: It is quite certain that virtue is the only and the highest good; that it alone richly abounds in the fruit of a blessed life; that a blessed life, by means of which eternal life is won, does not depend on external or corporal benefits, but on virtue only.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 5:11
verses.text: A blessed life is the fruit of the present, and eternal life is the hope of the future.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 5:12
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 5:13
verses.text: Some, however, there are who think a blessed life is impossible in this body, weak and fragile as it is.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 5:14
verses.text: For in it one must suffer pain and grief, one must weep, one must be ill.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 5:15
verses.text: So I could also say that a blessed life rests on bodily rejoicing, but not on the heights of wisdom, on the sweetness of conscience, or on the loftiness of virtue.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 5:16
verses.text: It is not a blessed thing to be in the midst of suffering; but it is blessed to be victorious over it, and not to be cowed by the power of temporal pain.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 5:17
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 5:18
verses.text: Suppose that things come which are accounted terrible as regards the grief they cause, such as blindness, exile, hunger, violation of a daughter, loss of children.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 5:19
verses.text: Who will deny that Isaac was blessed, who did not see in his old age, and yet gave blessings with his benediction? Was not Jacob blessed who, leaving his father's house, endured exile as a shepherd for pay, and mourned for the violated chastity of his daughter, and suffered hunger? Were they not blessed on whose good faith God received witness, as it is written: "The God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the  God of Jacob"? A wretched thing is slavery, but Joseph was not wretched; nay, clearly he was blessed, when he whilst in slavery checked the lusts of his mistress.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 5:20
verses.text: What shall I say of holy David who bewailed the death of three sons, and, what was even worse than this, his daughter's incestuous connection? How could he be unblessed from whom the Author of blessedness Himself sprung, Who has made many blessed? For: "Blessed are they who have not seen yet have believed".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 5:21
verses.text: All these felt their own weakness, but they bravely prevailed over it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 5:22
verses.text: What can we think of as more wretched than holy Job, either in the burning of his house, or the instantaneous death of his ten sons, or his bodily pains? Was he less blessed than if he had not endured those things whereby he really showed himself approved?  21.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 5:23
verses.text: True it is that in these sufferings there is something bitter, and that strength of mind cannot hide this pain.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 5:24
verses.text: I should not deny that the sea is deep because inshore it is shallow, nor that the sky is clear because sometimes it is covered with clouds, nor that the earth is fruitful because in some places there is but barren ground, nor that the crops are rich and full because they sometimes have wild oats mingled with them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 5:25
verses.text: So, too, count it as true that the harvest of a happy conscience may be mingled with some bitter feelings of grief.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 5:26
verses.text: In the sheaves of the whole of a blessed life, if by chance any misfortune or bitterness has crept in, is it not as though the wild oats were hidden, or as though the bitterness of the tares was concealed by the sweet scent of the corn? But let us now proceed again with our subject.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 6

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 6:1
verses.text: Chapter VI.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 6:2
verses.text: On what is useful: not that which is advantageous, but that which is just and virtuous.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 6:3
verses.text: It is to be found in losses, and is divided into what is useful for the body, and what is useful unto godliness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 6:4
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 6:5
verses.text: In the first book we made our division in such a way as to set in the first place what is virtuous and what is seemly; for all duties are derived from these.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 6:6
verses.text: In the second place we set what is useful.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 6:7
verses.text: But as at the start we said that there was a difference between what is virtuous and what is seemlywhich one can comprehend more easily than one can explainso also when we are thinking of what is useful, we have to give considerable thought to what is the more useful.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 6:8
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 6:9
verses.text: But we do not reckon usefulness by the value of any gain in money, but in acquiring godliness, as the Apostle says: "But godliness is profitable unto all things, having promise of the life that now is, and of that which is to come".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 6:10
verses.text: Thus in the holy Scriptures, if we look carefully we shall often find that what is virtuous is called useful: "All things are lawful unto me, but all things are not profitable" [useful].

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 6:11
verses.text: Before that he was speaking of vices, and so means: It is lawful to sin, but it is not seemly.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 6:12
verses.text: Sins rest in one's own power, but they are not virtuous.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 6:13
verses.text: To live wantonly is easy, but it is not right.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 6:14
verses.text: For food serves not God but the belly.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 6:15
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 6:16
verses.text: Therefore, because what is useful is also just, it is just to serve Christ, Who redeemed us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 6:17
verses.text: They too are just who for His Name's sake have given themselves up to death, they are unjust who have avoided it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 6:18
verses.text: Of them it says: What profit is there in my blood? that is: what advance has my justice made? Wherefore they also say: "Let us bind the just, for he is useless to us," that is: he is unjust, for he complains of us, condemns and rebukes us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 6:19
verses.text: This could also be referred to the greed of impious men, which closely resembles treachery; as we read in the case of the traitor Judas, who in his longing for gain and his desire for money put his head into the noose of treachery and fell.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 6:20
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 6:21
verses.text: We have then to speak of that usefulness which is full of what is virtuous, as the Apostle himself has laid it down in so many words, saying: "And this I speak for your own profit, not that I may cast a snare upon you, but for that which is comely".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 6:22
verses.text: It is plain, then, that what is virtuous is useful, and what is useful is virtuous; also that what is useful is just, and what is just is useful.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 6:23
verses.text: I can say this, for I am speaking, not to merchants who are covetous from a desire to make gain, but to my children.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 6:24
verses.text: And I am speaking of the duties which I wish to impress upon and impart to you, whom I have chosen for the service of the Lord; so that those things which have been already implanted and fixed in your minds and characters by habit and training may now be further unfolded to you by explanation and instruction.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 6:25
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 6:26
verses.text: Therefore as I am about to speak of what is useful, I will take up those words of  the Prophet: "Incline my heart unto Thy testimonies and not to covetousness," that the sound of the word "useful" may not rouse in us the desire for money.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 6:27
verses.text: Some indeed put it thus: "Incline my heart unto Thy testimonies and not to what is useful," that is, that kind of usefulness which is always on the watch for making gains in business, and has been bent and diverted by the habits of men to the pursuit of money.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 6:28
verses.text: For as a rule most people call that only useful which is profitable, but we are speaking of that kind of usefulness which is sought in earthly loss "that we may gain Christ," whose gain is "godliness with contentment".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 6:29
verses.text: Great, too, is the gain whereby we attain to godliness, which is rich with God, not indeed in fleeting wealth, but in eternal gifts, and in which rests no uncertain trial but grace constant and unending.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 6:30
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 6:31
verses.text: There is therefore a usefulness connected with the body, and also one that has to do with godliness, according to the Apostle's division: "Bodily exercise profiteth a little, but godliness is profitable unto all things".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 6:32
verses.text: And what is so virtuous as integrity? what so seemly as to preserve the body unspotted and undefiled, and its purity unsullied? What, again, is so seemly as that a widow should keep her plighted troth to her dead husband? What more useful than this whereby the heavenly kingdom is attained? For "there are some who have made themselves eunuchs for the kingdom of heaven's sake".

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:1
verses.text: Chapter VII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:2
verses.text: What is useful is the same as what is virtuous; nothing is more useful than love, which is gained by gentleness, courtesy, kindness, justice, and the other virtues, as we are given to understand from the histories of Moses and David.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:3
verses.text: Lastly, confidence springs from love, and again love from confidence.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:4
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:5
verses.text: There is therefore not only a close intercourse between what is virtuous and what is useful, but the same thing is both useful and virtuous.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:6
verses.text: Therefore He Who willed to open the kingdom of heaven to all sought not what was useful to Himself, but what was useful for all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:7
verses.text: Thus we must have a certain order and proceed step by step from habitual or common acts to those which are more excellent, so as to show by many examples the advancement of what is useful.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:8
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:9
verses.text: And first we may know there is nothing so useful as to be loved, nothing so useless as not to be loved; for to be hated in my opinion is simply fatal and altogether deadly.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:10
verses.text: We speak of this, then, in order that we may take care to give cause for a good estimate and opinion to be formed of us, and may try to get a place in others' affections through our calmness of mind and kindness of soul.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:11
verses.text: For goodness is agreeable and pleasing to all, and there is nothing that so easily reaches human feelings.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:12
verses.text: And if that is assisted by gentleness of character and willingness, as well as by moderation in giving orders and courtesy of speech, by honour in word, by a ready interchange of conversation and by the grace of modesty, it is incredible how much all this tends to an increase of love.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:13
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:14
verses.text: We read, not only in the case of private individuals but even of kings, what is the effect of ready and willing courtesy, and what harm pride and great swelling words have done, so far as to make even kingdoms to totter and powers to be destroyed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:15
verses.text: If any one gains the people's favour by advice or service, by fulfilling the duties of his ministry or office, or if he encounters danger for the sake of the whole nation, there is no doubt but that such love will be shown him by the people that they all will put his safety and welfare before their own.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:16
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:17
verses.text: What reproaches Moses had to bear from his people! But when the Lord would have avenged him on those who reviled him, he often used to offer himself for the people that he might save them from the divine anger.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:18
verses.text: With what gentle words used he to address the people, even after he was wronged! He comforted them in their labours, consoled them by his prophetic declarations of the future, and encouraged them by his works.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:19
verses.text: And though he often spoke with God, yet he was wont to address men gently and pleasantly.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:20
verses.text: Worthily was he considered to stand above all men.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:21
verses.text: For they could not even look on his face, and refused to believe that his sepulchre was found.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:22
verses.text: He had captivated the minds of all the people to such an extent; that they loved him even more for his gentleness than they admired him for his deeds.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:23
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:24
verses.text: There is David too who followed his steps, who was chosen from among all to rule the people.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:25
verses.text: How gentle and kindly he was, humble in spirit too, how diligent and ready to show affection.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:26
verses.text: Before he came to the throne he offered himself in the stead of  all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:27
verses.text: As king he showed himself an equal to all in warfare, and shared in their labours.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:28
verses.text: He was brave in battle, gentle in ruling, patient under abuse, and more ready to bear than to return wrongs.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:29
verses.text: So dear was he to all, that though a youth, he was chosen even against his will to rule over them, and was made to undertake the duty though he withstood it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:30
verses.text: When old he was asked by his people not to engage in battle, because they all preferred to incur danger for his sake rather than that he should undergo it for theirs.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:31
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:32
verses.text: He had bound the people to himself freely in doing his duty; first, when he during the division among the people preferred to live like an exile at Hebron rather than to reign at Jerusalem; next, when he showed that he loved valour even in an enemy.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:33
verses.text: He had also thought that justice should be shown to those who had borne arms against himself the same as to his own men.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:34
verses.text: Again, he admired Abner, the bravest champion of the opposing side, whilst he was their leader and was yet waging war.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:35
verses.text: Nor did he despise him when suing for peace, but honoured him by a banquet.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:36
verses.text: When killed by treachery, he mourned and wept for him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:37
verses.text: He followed him and honoured his obsequies, and evinced his good faith in desiring vengeance for the murder; for he handed on that duty to his son in the charge that he gave him, being anxious rather that the death of an innocent man should not be left unavenged, than that any one should mourn for his own.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:38
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:39
verses.text: It is no small thing, especially in the case of a king, so to perform humble duties as to make oneself like the very lowest.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:40
verses.text: It is noble not to seek for food at another's risk and to refuse a drink of water, to confess a sin, and to offer oneself to death for one's people.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:41
verses.text: This latter David did, so that the divine anger might be turned against himself, when he offered himself to the destroying angel and said: "Lo I have sinned: I the shepherd have done wickedly, but this flock, what hath it done? Let Thy hand be against me".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:42
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:43
verses.text: What further should I say? He opened not his mouth to those planning deceit, and, as though hearing not, he thought no word should be returned, nor did be answer their reproaches.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:44
verses.text: When he was evil spoken of, he prayed, when he was cursed, he blessed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:45
verses.text: He walked in simplicity of heart, and fled from the proud.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:46
verses.text: He was a follower of those unspotted from the world, one who mixed ashes with his food when bewailing his sins, and mingled his drink with weeping.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:47
verses.text: Worthily, then, was he called for by all the people.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:48
verses.text: All the tribes of Israel came to him saying: "Behold, we are thy bone and thy flesh.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:49
verses.text: Also yesterday and the day before when Saul lived, and reigned, thou wast he that leddest out and broughtest in Israel.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:50
verses.text: And the Lord said to thee, Thou shalt feed My people!" And why should I say more about him of whom the word of the Lord has gone forth to say: "I have found David according to My heart"? Who ever walked in holiness of heart and in justice as he did, so as to fulfil the will of God; for whose sake pardon was granted to his children when they sinned, and their rights were preserved to his heirs?  36.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:51
verses.text: Who would not have loved him, when they saw how dear he was to his friends? For as he truly loved his friends, so he thought that he was loved as much in return by his own friends.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:52
verses.text: Nay, parents put him even before their own children, and children loved him more than their parents.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:53
verses.text: Wherefore Saul was very angry and strove to strike Jonathan his son with a spear because he thought that David's friendship held a higher place in his esteem than either filial piety or a father's authority.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:54
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:55
verses.text: It gives a very great impetus to mutual love if one shows love in return to those who love us and proves that one does not love them less than oneself is loved, especially if one shows it by the proofs that a faithful friendship gives.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:56
verses.text: What is so likely to win favour as gratitude? What more natural than to love one who loves us? What so implanted and so impressed on men's feelings as the wish to let another, by whom we want to be loved, know that we love him? Well does the wise man say: "Lose thy money for thy brother and thy friend".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:57
verses.text: And again: "I will not be ashamed to defend a friend, neither will I hide myself from him".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:58
verses.text: If, indeed, the words in Ecclesiasticus testify that the medicine of life and immortality is in a friend; yet none has ever doubted that it is in love that our best defence lies.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:59
verses.text: As the Apostle says: "It beareth all things, believeth all things, hopeth all things, endureth all things; love never faileth".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:60
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:61
verses.text: Thus David failed not, for he was  dear to all, and wished to be loved rather than feared by his subjects.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:62
verses.text: Fear keeps the watch of temporal protection, but knows not how to keep guard permanently.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:63
verses.text: And so where fear has departed, boldness often creeps in; for fear does not force confidence but affection calls it forth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:64
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:65
verses.text: Love, then, is the first thing to give us a recommendation.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:66
verses.text: It is a good thing therefore to have our witness in the love of many.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:67
verses.text: Then arises confidence, so that even strangers are not afraid to trust themselves to thy kindness, when they see thee so dear to many.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 7:68
verses.text: So likewise one goes through confidence to love, so that he who has shown good faith to one or two has an influence as it were on the minds of all, and wins the good-will of all.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:1
verses.text: Chapter VIII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:2
verses.text: Nothing has greater effect in gaining good-will than giving advice; but none can trust it unless it rests on justice and prudence.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:3
verses.text: How conspicuous these two virtues were in Solomon is shown by his well-known judgment.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:4
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:5
verses.text: Two things, therefore, love and confidence, are the most efficacious in commending us to others; also this third quality if thou hast it, namely, what many consider to be worthy of admiration in thee, and think to be rightly worthy of honour [the power, in fact, of giving good advice].

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:6
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:7
verses.text: Since the giving of good advice is a great means of gaining men's affections, prudence and justice are much needed in every case.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:8
verses.text: These are looked for by most, so that confidence at once is placed in him in whom they exist, because he can give useful and trustworthy advice to whoever wants it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:9
verses.text: Who will put himself into the hands of a man whom he does not think to be more wise than himself who asks for advice? It is necessary therefore that he of whom advice is asked should be superior to him who asks it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:10
verses.text: For why should we consult a man when we do not think that he can make anything more plain than we ourselves see it?  42.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:11
verses.text: But if we have found a man that by the vigour of his character, by his strength of mind and influence, stands forth above all others, and further, is better fitted by example and experience than others; that can put an end to immediate dangers, foresee future ones, point out those close at hand, can explain a subject, bring relief in time, is ready not only to give advice but also to give help,in such a man confidence is placed, so that he who seeks advice can say: "Though evil should happen to me through him, I will bear it".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:12
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:13
verses.text: To a man of this sort then we entrust our safety and our reputation, for he is, as we said before, just and prudent.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:14
verses.text: Justice causes us to have no fear of deceit, and prudence frees us from having any suspicions of error.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:15
verses.text: However, we trust ourselves more readily to a just than to a prudent man, to put it in the way people generally do.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:16
verses.text: But, according to the definition of the philosophers, where there is one virtue, others exist too, whilst prudence cannot exist without justice.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:17
verses.text: We find this stated also in our writers, for David says: "The just showeth mercy and lendeth".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:18
verses.text: What the just lends, he says elsewhere: "A good man is he that showeth mercy and lendeth, he will guide his words with discretion".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:19
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:20
verses.text: Is not that noble judgment of Solomon full of wisdom and justice? Let us see whether it is so.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:21
verses.text: "Two women," it says, "stood before King Solomon, and the one said to him, Hear me, my lord, I and this woman dwell in one house, and before the third day we gave birth and bore a son apiece, and were together, there was no witness in the house, nor any other woman with us, only we two alone.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:22
verses.text: And her son died this night, because she overlaid it, and she arose at midnight, and took my son from my breast, and laid it in her bosom, and her dead child she laid at my breast.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:23
verses.text: And I arose in the morning to give my child suck, and found him dead.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:24
verses.text: And I considered it at dawn, and behold it was not my son.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:25
verses.text: And the other woman said, Nay, but the living is my son, and the dead is thy son".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:26
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:27
verses.text: This was their dispute, in which either tried to claim the living child for herself, and denied that the dead one was hers.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:28
verses.text: Then the king commanded a sword to be brought and the infant to be cut in half, and either piece to be given to one, one half to the one, and one half to the other.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:29
verses.text: Then the woman whose the child really was, moved by her feelings, cried out: "Divide not the child, my lord; let it rather be given to her and live, and do not kill it".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:30
verses.text: But the other answered: "Let it be neither mine nor hers, divide it".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:31
verses.text: Then the king ordered that the  infant should be given to the woman who had said: Do not kill it, but give it to that woman; "For," as it says, "her bowels yearned upon her son".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:32
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:33
verses.text: It is not wrong to suppose that the mind of God was in him; for what is hidden from God? What can be more hidden than the witness that lies deep within; into which the mind of the wise king entered as though to judge a mother's feelings, and elicited as it were the voice of a mother's heart.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:34
verses.text: For a mother's feelings were laid bare, when she chose that her son should live with another, rather than that he should be killed in his mother's sight.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:35
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:36
verses.text: It was therefore a sign of wisdom to distinguish between secret heart-thoughts, to draw the truth from hidden springs, and to pierce as it were with the sword of the Spirit not only the inward parts of the body, but even of the mind and soul.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:37
verses.text: It was the part of justice also that she who had killed her own child should not take away another's, but that the real mother should have her own back again.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:38
verses.text: Indeed the Scriptures have declared this.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:39
verses.text: "All Israel," it says, "heard of the judgment which the king had judged, and they feared the king, for they saw that the wisdom of God was in him to do judgment".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 8:40
verses.text: Solomon also himself had asked for wisdom, so that a prudent heart might be given him to hear and to judge with justice.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 9

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 9:1
verses.text: Chapter IX.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 9:2
verses.text: Though justice and prudence are inseparable, we must have respect to the ideas of people in general, for they make a distinction between the different cardinal virtues.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 9:3
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 9:4
verses.text: It is clear also, according to the sacred Scriptures, which are the older, that wisdom cannot exist without justice, for where one of these two is, there the other must be also.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 9:5
verses.text: With what wisdom did Daniel expose the lie in the false accusation brought against him by his thorough examination, so that those false informers had no answer ready to hand! It was a mark of prudence to convict the criminals by the witness of their own words, and a sign of justice to give over the guilty to punishment, and to save the innocent from it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 9:6
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 9:7
verses.text: There is therefore an inseparable union between wisdom and justice; but, generally speaking, the one special form of virtue is divided up.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 9:8
verses.text: Thus temperance lies in despising pleasures, fortitude may be seen in undergoing labours and dangers, prudence in the choice of what is good, by knowing how to distinguish between things useful and the reverse; justice, in being a good guardian of another's rights and protector of its own, thus maintaining for each his own.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 9:9
verses.text: We can make this fourfold division in deference to commonly received ideas; and so, whilst deviating from those subtle discussions of philosophic learning which are brought forth as though from some inner recess for the sake of investigating the truth, can follow the commonly received use and their ordinary meaning.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 9:10
verses.text: Keeping, then, to this division, let us return to our subject.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 10

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 10:1
verses.text: Chapter X.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 10:2
verses.text: Men entrust their safety rather to a just than to a prudent man.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 10:3
verses.text: But every one is wont to seek out the man who combines in himself the qualities of justice and prudence.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 10:4
verses.text: Solomon gives us an example of this.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 10:5
verses.text: (The words which the queen of Sheba spoke of him are explained.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 10:6
verses.text: ) Also Daniel and Joseph.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 10:7
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 10:8
verses.text: We entrust our case to the most prudent man we can find, and ask advice from him more readily than we do from others.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 10:9
verses.text: However, the faithful counsel of a just man stands first and often has more weight than the great abilities of the wisest of men: "For better are the wounds of a friend than the kisses of others".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 10:10
verses.text: And just because it is the judgment of a just man, it is also the conclusion of a wise one: in the one lies the result of the matter in dispute, in the other readiness of invention.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 10:11
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 10:12
verses.text: And if one connects the two, there will be great soundness in the advice given, which is regarded by all with admiration for the wisdom shown, and with love for its justice.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 10:13
verses.text: And so all will desire to hear the wisdom of that man in whom those two virtues are found together, as all the kings of the earth desired to see the face of Solomon and to hear his wisdom.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 10:14
verses.text: Nay, even the queen of Sheba came to him and tried him with questions.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 10:15
verses.text: She came and spoke of all the things that were in her heart, and heard all the wisdom of Solomon, nor did any word escape her.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 10:16
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 10:17
verses.text: Who she was whom nothing escaped, and that there was nothing which the truth-loving Solomon did not tell her, learn, O man, from this which thou hearest her saying: "It was a true report that I heard in  mine own land of thy words and of thy prudence, yet I did not believe those that told it me until I came, and mine eyes had seen it; and behold the half was not told me.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 10:18
verses.text: Thou hast added good things over and above all that I heard in mine own land.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 10:19
verses.text: Blessed are thy women and blessed thy servants, which stand before thee, and that hear all thy prudence".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 10:20
verses.text: Recognize the feast of the true Solomon, and who are set down at that feast; recognize it wisely and think in what land all the nations shall hear the fame of true wisdom and justice, and with what eyes they shall see Him, beholding those things which are not seen.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 10:21
verses.text: "For the things that are seen are temporal, but the things which are not seen are eternal".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 10:22
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 10:23
verses.text: What women are blessed but those of whom it is said "that many hear the word of God and bring forth fruit"? And again: "Whosoever doeth the word of God is My father and sister and mother".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 10:24
verses.text: And who are those blessed servants, who stand before Him, but Paul, who said: "Even to this day I stand witnessing both to great and small;" or Simeon, who was waiting in the temple to see the consolation of Israel? How could he have asked to be let depart, except that in standing before the Lord he had not the power of departing, but only according to the will of God? Solomon is put before us simply for the sake of example, of whom it was eagerly expected that his wisdom should be heard.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 10:25
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 10:26
verses.text: Joseph also when in prison was not free from being consulted about matters of uncertainty.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 10:27
verses.text: His counsel was of advantage to the whole of Egypt, so that it felt not the seven years' famine, and he was able even to relieve other peoples from their dreadful hunger.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 10:28
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 10:29
verses.text: Daniel, though one of the captives, was made the head of the royal counsellors.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 10:30
verses.text: By his counsels he improved the present and foretold the future.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 10:31
verses.text: Confidence was put in him in all things, because he had frequently interpreted things, and had shown that he had declared the truth.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 11

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 11:1
verses.text: Chapter XI.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 11:2
verses.text: A third element which tends to gain any one's confidence is shown to have been conspicuous in Moses, Daniel, and Joseph.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 11:3
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 11:4
verses.text: But a third point seems also to have been noted in the case of those who were thought worthy of admiration after the example of Joseph, Solomon, and Daniel.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 11:5
verses.text: For what shall I say of Moses whose advice all Israel always waited for, whose life caused them to trust in his prudence and increased their esteem for him? Who would not trust to the counsel of Moses, to whom the elders reserved for decision whatever they thought beyond their understanding and powers?  57.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 11:6
verses.text: Who would refuse the counsel of Daniel, of whom God Himself said: "Who is wiser than Daniel?" How can men doubt about the minds of those to whom God has given such grace? By the counsel of Moses wars were brought to an end, and for his merit's sake food came from heaven and drink from the rock.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 11:7
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 11:8
verses.text: How pure must have been the soul of Daniel to soften the character of barbarians and to tame the lions! What temperance was his, what self-restraint in soul and body! Not unworthily did he become an object of admiration to all, whenand all men do admire this,though enjoying royal friendships, he sought not for gold, nor counted the honour given him as more precious than his faith.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 11:9
verses.text: For he was willing to endure danger for the law of God rather than to be turned from his purpose in order to gain the favour of men.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 11:10
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 11:11
verses.text: And what, again, shall I say of the chastity and justice of Joseph, whom I had almost passed by, whereby on the one hand he rejected the allurements of his mistress and refused rewards, on the other he mocked at death, repressed his fear, and chose a prison? Who would not consider him a fit person to give advice in a private case, whose fruitful spirit and fertile mind enriched the barrenness of the time with the wealth of his counsels and heart?.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 12

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 12:1
verses.text: Chapter XII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 12:2
verses.text: No one asks counsel from a man tainted with vice, or from one who is morose or impracticable, but rather from one of whom we have a pattern in the Scriptures.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 12:3
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 12:4
verses.text: We note therefore that in seeking for counsel, uprightness of life, excellence in virtues, habits of benevolence, and the charm of good-nature have very great weight.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 12:5
verses.text: Who seeks for a spring in the mud? Who wants to drink from muddy water? So  where there is luxurious living, excess, and a union of vices, who will think that he ought to draw from that source? Who does not despise a foul life? Who will think a man to be useful to another's cause whom he sees to be useless in his own life? Who, again, does not avoid a wicked, ill-disposed, abusive person, who is always ready to do harm? Who would not be only too eager to avoid him?  61.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 12:6
verses.text: And who will come to a man however well fitted to give the best of advice who is nevertheless hard to approach? It goes with him as with a fountain whose waters are shut off.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 12:7
verses.text: What is the advantage of having wisdom, if one refuses to give advice? If one cuts off the opportunities of giving advice, the source is closed, so as no longer to flow for others or to be of any good to oneself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 12:8
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 12:9
verses.text: Well can we refer this to him who, possessing prudence, has defiled it with the foulness of a vicious life and so pollutes the water at the source.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 12:10
verses.text: His life is a proof of a degenerate spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 12:11
verses.text: How can one judge him to be good in counsel whom one sees to be evil in character? He ought to be superior to me, if I am ready to trust myself to him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 12:12
verses.text: Am I to suppose that he is fit to give me advice who never takes it for himself, or am I to believe that he has time to give to me when he has none for himself, when his mind is filled with pleasures, and he is overcome by lust, is the slave of avarice, is excited by greed, and is terrified with fright? How is there room for counsel here where there is none for quiet?  63.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 12:13
verses.text: That man of counsel whom I must admire and look up to, whom the gracious Lord gave to our fathers, put aside all that was offensive.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 12:14
verses.text: His follower he ought to be, who can give counsel and protect another's prudence from vice; for nothing foul can mingle with that.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 13

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 13:1
verses.text: Chapter XIII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 13:2
verses.text: The beauty of wisdom is made plain by the divine testimony.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 13:3
verses.text: From this he goes on to prove its connection with the other virtues.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 13:4
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 13:5
verses.text: Is there any one who would like to be beautiful in face and at the same time to have its charm spoilt by a beast-like body and fearful talons? Now the form of virtues is so wonderful and glorious, and especially the beauty of wisdom, as the whole of the Scriptures tell us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 13:6
verses.text: For it is more brilliant than the sun, and when compared with the stars far outshines any constellation.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 13:7
verses.text: Night takes their light away in its train, but wickedness cannot overcome wisdom.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 13:8
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 13:9
verses.text: We have spoken of its beauty, and proved it by the witness of Scripture.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 13:10
verses.text: It remains to show on the authority of Scripture that there can be no fellowship between it and vice, but that it has an inseparable union with the rest of the virtues.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 13:11
verses.text: "It has a spirit sagacious, undefiled, sure, holy, loving what is good, quick, that never forbids a kindness, kind, steadfast, free from care, having all power, overseeing all things".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 13:12
verses.text: And again: "She teacheth temperance and justice and virtue".

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 14

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 14:1
verses.text: Chapter XIV.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 14:2
verses.text: Prudence is combined with all the virtues, especially with contempt of riches.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 14:3
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 14:4
verses.text: Prudence, therefore, works through all things, she has fellowship with all that is good.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 14:5
verses.text: For how can she give good advice unless she have justice too, so that she may clothe herself in consistency, not fear death, be held back by no alarm, no fear, nor think it right to be turned aside from the truth by any flattery, nor shun exile, knowing that the world is the fatherland of the wise man.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 14:6
verses.text: She fears not want, for she knows that nothing is wanting to the wise man, since the whole world of riches is his.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 14:7
verses.text: What is greater than the man that knows not how to be excited at the thought of money, and has a contempt for riches, and looks down as from some lofty vantage-ground on the desires of men? Men think that one who acts thus is more than man: "Who is this," it says, "and we will praise him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 14:8
verses.text: For wonderful things hath he done in his life".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 14:9
verses.text: Surely he ought to be admired who despises riches, seeing that most place them even before their own safety.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 14:10
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 14:11
verses.text: The rule of economy and the authority of self-restraint befits all, and most of all him who stands highest in honour; so that no love for his treasures may seize upon such a man, and that he who rules over free men may never become a slave to money.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 14:12
verses.text: It is more seemly that in soul he should be superior to treasures, and in willing service be subject to his friends.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 14:13
verses.text: For humility increases the regard in which one is held.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 14:14
verses.text: It is praiseworthy and right for the chief of men to have no desire for filthy lucre in common with Syrian traders and Gilead merchants, nor to place all their hope of good in money, or to count up their daily gains and to calculate their savings like a hireling.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:1
verses.text: Chapter XV.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:2
verses.text: Of liberality.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:3
verses.text: To whom it must chiefly be shown, and how men of slender means may show it by giving their service and counsel.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:4
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:5
verses.text: But if it is praiseworthy to have one's soul free from this failing, how much more glorious is it to gain the love of the people by liberality which is neither too freely shown to those who are unsuitable, nor too sparingly bestowed upon the needy.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:6
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:7
verses.text: There are many kinds of liberality.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:8
verses.text: Not only can we distribute and give away food to those who need it from our own daily supply, so that they may sustain life; but we can also give advice and help to those who are ashamed to show their want openly, so long as the common supplies of the needy are not exhausted.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:9
verses.text: I am now speaking of one set over some office.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:10
verses.text: If he is a priest or almoner, let him inform the bishop of them, and not withhold the name of any he knows to be in any need, or to have lost their wealth and to be now reduced to want; especially if they have not fallen into this trouble owing to wastefulness in youth, but because of another's theft, or through loss of their inheritance from no fault of their own, so that they cannot now earn their daily bread.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:11
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:12
verses.text: The highest kind of liberality is, to redeem captives, to save them from the hands of their enemies, to snatch men from death, and, most of all, women from shame, to restore children to their parents, parents to their children, and, to give back a citizen to his country.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:13
verses.text: This was recognized when Thrace and Illyria were so terribly devastated.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:14
verses.text: How many captives were then for sale all over the world! Could one but call them together, their number would have surpassed that of a whole province.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:15
verses.text: Yet there were some who would have sent back into slavery those whom the Church had redeemed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:16
verses.text: They themselves were harder than slavery itself to look askance at another's mercy.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:17
verses.text: If they themselves (they said) had come to slavery, they would be slaves freely.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:18
verses.text: If they had been sold, they would not refuse the service of slavery.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:19
verses.text: They wished to undo the freedom of others, though they could not undo their own slavery, unless perchance it should please the buyer to receive his price again, whereby, however, slavery would not be simply undone but redeemed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:20
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:21
verses.text: It is then a special quality of liberality to redeem captives, especially from barbarian enemies who are moved by no spark of human feeling to show mercy, except so far as avarice has preserved it with a view to redemption.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:22
verses.text: It is also a great thing to take upon oneself another's debt, if the debtor cannot pay and is hard pressed to do so, and where the money is due by right and is only left unpaid through want.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:23
verses.text: So, too, it is a sign of great liberality to bring up children, and to take care of orphans.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:24
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:25
verses.text: There are others who place in marriage maidens that have lost their parents, so as to preserve their chastity, and who help them not only with good wishes but also by a sum of money.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:26
verses.text: There is also another kind of liberality which the Apostle teaches: "If any that believeth hath widows let him relieve them, that the Church be not burdened by supplying them, that it may have enough for those that are widows indeed".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:27
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:28
verses.text: Useful, then, is liberality of this sort; but it is not common to all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:29
verses.text: For there are many good men who have but slender means, and are content with little for their own use, and are not able to give help to lighten the poverty of others.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:30
verses.text: However, another sort of kindness is ready to their hand, whereby they can help those poorer still.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:31
verses.text: For there is a twofold liberality: one that gives actual assistance, that is, in money; the other, which is busy in offering active help, is often much grander and nobler.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:32
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:33
verses.text: How much grander it was for Abraham to have recovered his captured son-in-law by his victorious arms, than if he had ransomed him! How much more usefully did holy Joseph help King Pharaoh by his counsel to provide for the future, than if he had offered him money! For money would not have bought back the fruitfulness of any  one state; whilst he by his foresight kept the famine for five years from the whole of Egypt.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:34
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:35
verses.text: Money is easily spent; counsels can never be exhausted.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:36
verses.text: They only grow the stronger by constant use.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:37
verses.text: Money grows less and quickly comes to an end, and has failed even kindness itself; so that the more there are to whom one wants to give, the fewer one can help; and often one has not got what one thinks ought to be given to others.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:38
