verses.text: But as regards the offer of advice and active help, the more there are to spend it on, the more there seems to be, and the more it returns to its own source.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 15:39
verses.text: The rich stream of prudence ever flows back upon itself, and the more it has reached out to, so much the more active becomes all that remains.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:1
verses.text: Chapter XVI.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:2
verses.text: Due measure must be observed in liberality, that it may not be expended on worthless persons, when it is needed by worthier ones.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:3
verses.text: However, alms are not to be given in too sparing and hesitating a way.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:4
verses.text: One ought rather to follow the example of the blessed Joseph, whose prudence is commended at great length.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:5
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:6
verses.text: It is clear, then, that there ought to be due measure in our liberality, that our gifts may not become useless.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:7
verses.text: Moderation must be observed, especially by priests, for fear that they should give away for the sake of ostentation, and not for justice' sake.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:8
verses.text: Never was the greed of beggars greater than it is now.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:9
verses.text: They come in full vigour, they come with no reason but that they are on the tramp.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:10
verses.text: They want to empty the purses of the poorto deprive them of their means of support.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:11
verses.text: Not content with a little, they ask for more.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:12
verses.text: In the clothes that cover them they seek a ground to urge their demands, and with lies about their lives they ask for further sums of money.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:13
verses.text: If any one were to trust their tale too readily, he would quickly drain the fund which is meant to serve for the sustenance of the poor.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:14
verses.text: Let there be method in our giving, so that the poor may not go away empty nor the subsistence of the needy be done away and become the spoil of the dishonest.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:15
verses.text: Let there be then such due measure that kindness may never be put aside, and true need never be left neglected.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:16
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:17
verses.text: Many pretend they have debts.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:18
verses.text: Let the truth be looked into.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:19
verses.text: They bemoan the fact that they have been stripped of everything by robbers.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:20
verses.text: In such a case give credit only if the misfortune is apparent, or the person is well known; and then readily give help.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:21
verses.text: To those rejected by the Church supplies must be granted if they are in want of food.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:22
verses.text: He, then, that observes method in his giving is hard towards none, but is free towards all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:23
verses.text: We ought not only to lend our ears to hear the voices of those who plead, but also our eyes to look into their needs.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:24
verses.text: Weakness calls more loudly to the good dispenser than the voice of the poor.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:25
verses.text: It cannot always be that the cries of an importunate beggar will never extort more, but let us not always give way to impudence.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:26
verses.text: He must be seen who does not see thee.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:27
verses.text: He must be sought for who is ashamed to be seen.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:28
verses.text: He also that is in prison must come to thy thoughts; another seized with sickness must present himself to thy mind, as he cannot reach thy ears.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:29
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:30
verses.text: The more people see thy zeal in showing mercy, the more will they love thee.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:31
verses.text: I know many priests who had the more, the more they gave.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:32
verses.text: For they who see a good dispenser give him something to distribute in his round of duty, sure that the act of mercy will reach the poor.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:33
verses.text: If they see him giving away either in excess or too sparingly, they contemn either of these; in the one case because he wastes the fruits of another's labours by unnecessary payments, on the other hand because he hoards them in his money bags.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:34
verses.text: As, then, method must be observed in liberality, so also at times it seems as though the spur must be applied.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:35
verses.text: Method, then, so that the kindness one shows may be able to be shown day by day, and that we may not have to withdraw from a needful case what we have freely spent on waste.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:36
verses.text: A spur, because money is better laid out in food for the poor than on a purse for the rich.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:37
verses.text: We must take care lest in our money chests we shut up the welfare of the needy, and bury the life of the poor as it were in a sepulchre.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:38
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:39
verses.text: Joseph could have given away all the wealth of Egypt, and have spent the royal treasures; but he would not even seem to be wasteful of what was another's.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:40
verses.text: He preferred to sell the corn rather than to give it to the hungry.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:41
verses.text: For if he had given it to a few there would have been none for most.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:42
verses.text: He gave good proof of that liberality whereby there was enough for all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:43
verses.text: He opened the storehouses that all might buy their corn supply, lest if they received it for nothing, they should give up cultivating the  ground.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:44
verses.text: For he who has the use of what is another's often neglects his own.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:45
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:46
verses.text: First of all, then, he gathered up their money, then their implements, last of all he acquired for the king all their rights to the ground.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:47
verses.text: He did not wish to deprive all of them of their property, but to support them in it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:48
verses.text: He also imposed a general tax, that they might hold their own in safety.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:49
verses.text: So pleasing was this to all from whom he had taken the land, that they looked on it, not as the selling of their rights, but as the recovery of their welfare.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:50
verses.text: Thus they spoke: "Thou hast saved our lives, let us find grace in the sight of our Lord".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:51
verses.text: For they had lost nothing of their own, but had received a new right.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:52
verses.text: Nothing of what was useful to them had failed, for they had now gained it in perpetuity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:53
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:54
verses.text: O noble man! who sought not for the fleeting glory of a needless bounty, but set up as his memorial the lasting benefits of his foresight.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:55
verses.text: He acted so that the people should help themselves by their payments, and should not in their time of need seek help from others.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:56
verses.text: For it was surely better to give up part of their crops than to lose the whole of their rights.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:57
verses.text: He fixed the impost at a fifth of their whole produce, and thus showed himself clear-sighted in making provision for the future, and liberal in the tax he laid upon them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:58
verses.text: Never after did Egypt suffer from such a famine.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:59
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:60
verses.text: How splendidly he inferred the future.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:61
verses.text: First, how acutely, when interpreting the royal dream, he stated the truth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:62
verses.text: This was the king's first dream.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:63
verses.text: Seven heifers came up out of the river well-favoured and fat-fleshed, and they fed at the banks of the river.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:64
verses.text: And other bullocks ill-favoured and lean-fleshed came up out of the river after the heifers, and fed near them on the very edge of the river.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:65
verses.text: And these thin and wretched bullocks seemed to devour those others which were so fat and well-favoured.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:66
verses.text: And this was the second dream.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:67
verses.text: Seven fat ears full and good came up from the ground.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:68
verses.text: And after them seven wretched ears, blasted with the wind and withered, endeavoured to take their place.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:69
verses.text: And it seemed that the barren and thin ears devoured the rich and fruitful ears.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:70
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:71
verses.text: This dream Joseph unfolded as follows: that the seven heifers were seven years, and the seven ears likewise were seven years,interpreting the times by the produce of cattle and crops.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:72
verses.text: For both the calving of a heifer takes a year, and the produce of a crop fills out a whole year.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:73
verses.text: And they came up out of the river just as days, years, and times pass by and flow along swiftly like the rivers.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:74
verses.text: He therefore states that the seven earlier years of a rich land will be fertile and fruitful but the latter seven years will be barren and unfruitful, whose barrenness will eat up the richness of the former time.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:75
verses.text: Wherefore he warns them to see that supplies of corn are got together in the fruitful years that they may help out the needs of the coming scarcity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:76
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:77
verses.text: What shall we admire first? His powers of mind, with which he descended to the very resting-place of truth? Or his counsel, whereby he foresaw so great and lasting a need? Or his watchfulness or justice? By his watchfulness, when so high an office was given him, he gathered together such vast supplies; and through his justice he treated all alike.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:78
verses.text: And what am I to say of his greatness of mind? For though sold by his brothers into slavery, he took no revenge for this wrong, but put an end to their want.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:79
verses.text: What of his gentleness, whereby by a pious fraud he sought to gain the presence of his beloved brother whom, under pretence of a well-planned theft, he declared to have stolen his property, that he might hold him as a hostage of his love?  85.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:80
verses.text: Whence it was deservedly said to him by his father: "My son Joseph is enlarged, my son is enlarged, my younger son, my beloved.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:81
verses.text: My God hath helped thee and blessed thee with the blessing of heaven above and the blessing of the earth, the earth that hath all things, on account of the blessings of thy father and thy mother.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:82
verses.text: It hath prevailed over the blessings of the everlasting hills and the desires of the eternal hills".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:83
verses.text: And in Deuteronomy: "Thou Who wast seen in the bush, that Thou mayest come upon the head of Joseph, upon his pate.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:84
verses.text: Honoured among his brethren, his glory is as the firstling of his bullocks; his horns are like the horns of unicorns.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:85
verses.text: With his horn he shall push the nations even to the ends of the earth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 16:86
verses.text: They are the ten thousands of Ephraim and the thousands of Manasseh".

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:1
verses.text: Chapter XVII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:2
verses.text: What virtues ought to exist in him whom we consult.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:3
verses.text: How Joseph and Paul were equipped with them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:4
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:5
verses.text: Such, then, ought he to be who gives counsel to another, in order that he may offer himself as a pattern in all good works, in teaching, in trueness of character, in seriousness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:6
verses.text: Thus his words will be wholesome and irreproachable, his counsel useful, his life virtuous, and his opinions seemly.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:7
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:8
verses.text: Such was Paul, who gave counsel to virgins, guidance to priests, so as to offer himself as a pattern for us to copy.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:9
verses.text: Thus he knew how to be humble, as also Joseph did, who, though sprung from the noble family of the patriarchs, was not ashamed of his base slavery; rather he adorned it with his ready service, and made it glorious by his virtues.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:10
verses.text: He knew how to be humble who had to go through the hands of both buyer and seller, and called them, Lord.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:11
verses.text: Hear him as he humbles himself: "My lord on my account knoweth not what is in his house, and he hath committed all that he hath to my hand, neither hath he kept back anything from me but thee, because thou art his wife; how, then, can I do this great wickedness, and sin against God?" Full of humility are his words, full, too, of chastity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:12
verses.text: Of humility, for he was obedient to his Lord; of an honourable spirit, for he was grateful; full, also, of chastity, for he thought it a terrible sin to be defiled by so great a crime.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:13
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:14
verses.text: Such, then, ought the man of counsel to be.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:15
verses.text: He must have nothing dark, or deceptive, or false about him, to cast a shadow on his life and character, nothing wicked or evil to keep back those who want advice.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:16
verses.text: For there are some things which one flies from, others which one despises.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:17
verses.text: We fly from those things which can do harm, or can perfidiously and quietly grow to do us hurt, as when he whose advice we ask is of doubtful honour, or is desirous of money, so that a certain sum can make him change his mind.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:18
verses.text: If a man acts unjustly, we fly from him and avoid him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:19
verses.text: A man that is a pleasure seeker and extravagant, although he does not act falsely, yet is avaricious and too fond of filthy lucre; such an one is despised.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:20
verses.text: What proof of hard work, what fruits of labour, can he give who gives himself up to a sluggish and idle life, or what cares and anxieties ever enter his mind?  89.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:21
verses.text: Therefore the man of good counsel says: "I have learnt in whatsoever state I am therewith to be content".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:22
verses.text: For he knew that the root of all evils is the love of money, and therefore he was content with what he had, without seeking for what was another's.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:23
verses.text: Sufficient for me, he says, is what I have; whether I have little or much, to me it is much.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:24
verses.text: It seems as though he wanted to state it as clearly as possible.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:25
verses.text: He makes use of these words: "I am content," he says, "with what I have".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:26
verses.text: That means: "I neither have want, nor have I too much.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:27
verses.text: I have no want, for I seek nothing more.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:28
verses.text: I have not too much, for I have it not for myself, but for the many".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:29
verses.text: This is said with reference to money.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:30
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:31
verses.text: But he could have said these words about everything, for all that he had at the moment contented him; that is, he wanted no greater honour, he sought for no further services, he was not desirous of vainglory, nor did he look for gratitude where it was not due; but patient in labours, sure in his merits, he waited for the end of the struggle that he must needs endure.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:32
verses.text: "I know," he says, "how to be abased".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:33
verses.text: An untaught humility has no claim to praise, but only that which possesses modesty and a knowledge of self.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:34
verses.text: For there is a humility that rests on fear, one, too, that rests on want of skill and ignorance.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:35
verses.text: Therefore the Scripture says: "He will save the humble in spirit".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:36
verses.text: Gloriously, therefore, does he say: "I know how to be abased;" that is to say, where, in what moderation, to what end, in what duty, in which office.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:37
verses.text: The Pharisee knew not how to be abased, therefore he was cast down.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:38
verses.text: The publican knew, and therefore he was justified.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:39
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:40
verses.text: Paul knew, too, how to abound, for he had a rich soul, though he possessed not the treasure of a rich man.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:41
verses.text: He knew how to abound, for he sought no gift in money, but looked for fruit in grace.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:42
verses.text: We can understand his words that he knew how to abound also in another way.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:43
verses.text: For he could say again: "O ye Corinthians, our mouth is open unto you, our heart is enlarged".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:44
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:45
verses.text: In all things he was accustomed both to be full and to be hungry.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:46
verses.text: Blessed is he that knows how to be full in Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:47
verses.text: Not corporal, but spiritual, is that satiety which knowledge brings about.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:48
verses.text: And rightly is  there need of knowledge: "For man lives not by bread alone, but by every word of God".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:49
verses.text: For he who knew how to be full also knew how to be hungry, so as to be always seeking something new, hungering after God, thirsting for the Lord.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:50
verses.text: He knew how to hunger, for he knew that the hungry shall eat.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 17:51
verses.text: He knew, also, how to abound, and was able to abound, for he had nothing and yet possessed all things.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 18

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 18:1
verses.text: Chapter XVIII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 18:2
verses.text: We learn from the fact of the separation of the ten tribes from King Rehoboam what harm bad counsellors can do.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 18:3
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 18:4
verses.text: Justice, then, especially graces men that are set over any office; on the other hand, injustice fails them and fights against them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 18:5
verses.text: Scripture itself gives us an example, where it says, that when the people of Israel, after the death of Solomon, had asked his son Rehoboam to free their neck from their cruel yoke, and to lighten the harshness of his father's rule, he, despising the counsel of the old men, gave the following answer at the suggestion of the young men: "He would add a burden to the yoke of his father, and change their lighter toils for harder".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 18:6
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 18:7
verses.text: Angered by this answer, the people said: "We have no portion in David, nor inheritance in the son of Jesse.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 18:8
verses.text: Return to your tents, O Israel.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 18:9
verses.text: For we will not have this man for a prince or a leader over us".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 18:10
verses.text: So, forsaken and deserted by the people, he could keep with him scarce two of the ten tribes for David's sake.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 19

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 19:1
verses.text: Chapter XIX.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 19:2
verses.text: Many are won by justice and benevolence and courtesy, but all this must be sincere.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 19:3
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 19:4
verses.text: It is plain, then, that equity strengthens empires, and injustice destroys them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 19:5
verses.text: How could wickedness hold fast a kingdom when it cannot even rule over a single family? There is need, therefore, of the greatest kindness, so that we may preserve not only the government of affairs in general, but also the rights of individuals.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 19:6
verses.text: Benevolence is of the greatest value; for it seeks to embrace all in its favours, to bind them to itself by fulfilling duties, and to pledge them to itself by its charm.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 19:7
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 19:8
verses.text: We have also said that courtesy of speech has great effect in winning favour.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 19:9
verses.text: But we want it to be sincere and sensible, without flattery, lest flattery should disgrace the simplicity and purity of our address.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 19:10
verses.text: We ought to be a pattern to others not only in act but also in word, in purity, and in faith.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 19:11
verses.text: What we wish to be thought, such let us be; and let us show openly such feelings as we have within us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 19:12
verses.text: Let us not say an unjust word in our heart that we think can be hid in silence, for He hears things said in secret Who made things secret, and knows the secrets of the heart, and has implanted feelings within.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 19:13
verses.text: Therefore as though under the eyes of the Judge let us consider all we do as set forth in the light, that it may be manifest to all.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:1
verses.text: Chapter XX.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:2
verses.text: Familiarity with good men is very advantageous to all, especially to the young, as is shown by the example of Joshua and Moses and others.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:3
verses.text: Further, those who are unlike in age are often alike in virtues, as Peter and John prove.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:4
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:5
verses.text: It is a very good thing to unite oneself to a good man.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:6
verses.text: It is also very useful for the young to follow the guidance of great and wise men.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:7
verses.text: For he who lives in company with wise men is wise himself; but he who clings to the foolish is looked on as a fool too.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:8
verses.text: This friendship with the wise is a great help in teaching us, and also as giving a sure proof of our uprightness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:9
verses.text: Young men show very soon that they imitate those to whom they attach themselves.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:10
verses.text: And this idea gains ground from the fact that in all their daily life they grow to be like those with whom they have enjoyed intercourse to the full.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:11
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:12
verses.text: Joshua the son of Nun became so great, because his union with Moses was the means not only of instructing him in a knowledge of the law, but also of sanctifying him to receive grace.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:13
verses.text: When in His tabernacle the majesty of the Lord was seen to shine forth in its divine Presence, Joshua alone was in the tabernacle.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:14
verses.text: When Moses spoke with God, Joshua too was covered by the sacred cloud.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:15
verses.text: The priests and people stood below, and Joshua and Moses went up the mount to receive the law.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:16
verses.text: All the people were within the camp;  Joshua was without the camp in the tabernacle of witness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:17
verses.text: When the pillar of a cloud came down, and God spoke with Moses, he stood as a trusty servant beside him; and he, a young man, did not go out of the tabernacle, though the old men who stood afar off trembled at these divine wonders.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:18
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:19
verses.text: Everywhere, therefore, he alone kept close to holy Moses amid all these wondrous works and dread secrets.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:20
verses.text: Wherefore it happens that he who had been his companion in this intercourse with God succeeded to his power.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:21
verses.text: Worthy surely was he to stand forth as a man who might stay the course of the river, and who might say: "Sun, stand still," and delay the night and lengthen the day, as though to witness his victory.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:22
verses.text: Why?a blessing denied to Moseshe alone was chosen to lead the people into the promised land.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:23
verses.text: A man he was, great in the wonders he wrought by faith, great in his triumphs.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:24
verses.text: The works of Moses were of a higher type, his brought greater success.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:25
verses.text: Either of these then aided by divine grace rose above all human standing.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:26
verses.text: The one ruled the sea, the other heaven.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:27
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:28
verses.text: Beautiful, therefore, is the union between old and young.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:29
verses.text: The one to give witness, the other to give comfort; the one to give guidance, the other to give pleasure.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:30
verses.text: I pass by Lot, who when young clung to Abraham, as he was setting out.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:31
verses.text: For some perhaps might say this arose rather owing to their relationship than from any voluntary action on his part.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:32
verses.text: And what are we to say of Elijah and Elisha? Though Scripture has not in so many words stated that Elisha was a young man, yet we gather from it that he was the younger.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:33
verses.text: In the Acts of the Apostles, Barnabas took Mark with him, and Paul took Silas and Timothy and Titus.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:34
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:35
verses.text: We see also that duties were divided amongst them according to their superiority in anything.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:36
verses.text: The elders took the lead in giving counsel, the younger in showing activity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:37
verses.text: Often, too, those who were alike in virtue but unlike in years were greatly rejoiced at their union, as Peter and John were.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:38
verses.text: We read in the Gospel that John was a young man, even in his own words, though he was behind none of the elders in merits and wisdom.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:39
verses.text: For in him there was a venerable ripeness of character and the prudence of the hoarhead.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 20:40
verses.text: An unspotted life is the due of a good old age.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:1
verses.text: Chapter XXI.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:2
verses.text: To defend the weak, or to help strangers, or to perform similar duties, greatly adds to one's worth, especially in the case of tried men.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:3
verses.text: Whilst one gets great blame for love of money; wastefulness, also, in the case of priests is very much condemned.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:4
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:5
verses.text: The regard in which one is held is also very much enhanced when one rescues a poor man out of the hands of a powerful one, or saves a condemned criminal from death; so long as it can be done without disturbance, for fear that we might seem to be doing it rather for the sake of showing off than for pity's sake, and so might inflict severer wounds whilst desiring to heal slighter ones.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:6
verses.text: But if one has freed a man who is crushed down by the resources and faction of a powerful person, rather than overwhelmed by the deserts of his own wickedness, then the witness of a great and high opinion grows strong.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:7
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:8
verses.text: Hospitality also serves to recommend many.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:9
verses.text: For it is a kind of open display of kindly feelings: so that the stranger may not want hospitality, but be courteously received, and that the door may be open to him when he comes.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:10
verses.text: It is most seemly in the eyes of the whole world that the stranger should be received with honour; that the charm of hospitality should not fail at our table; that we should meet a guest with ready and free service, and look out for his arrival.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:11
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:12
verses.text: This especially was Abraham's praise, for he watched at the door of his tent, that no stranger by any chance might pass by.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:13
verses.text: He carefully kept a lookout, so as to meet the stranger, and anticipate him, and ask him not to pass by, saying: "My lord, if I have found favour in thy sight, pass not by thy servant".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:14
verses.text: Therefore as a reward for his hospitality, he received the gift of posterity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:15
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:16
verses.text: Lot also, his nephew, who was near to him not only in relationship but also in virtue, on account of his readiness to show hospitality, turned aside the punishment of Sodom from himself and his family.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:17
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:18
verses.text: A man ought therefore to be hospitable, kind, upright, not desirous of what belongs to another, willing to give up some  of his own rights if assailed, rather than to take away another's.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:19
verses.text: He ought to avoid disputes, to hate quarrels.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:20
verses.text: He ought to restore unity and the grace of quietness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:21
verses.text: When a good man gives up any of his own rights, it is not only a sign of liberality, but is also accompanied by great advantages.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:22
verses.text: To start with, it is no small gain to be free from the cost of a lawsuit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:23
verses.text: Then it also brings in good results, by an increase of friendship, from which many advantages rise.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:24
verses.text: These become afterwards most useful to the man that can despise a little something at the time.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:25
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:26
verses.text: In all the duties of hospitality kindly feeling must be shown to all, but greater respect must be given to the upright.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:27
verses.text: For "Whosoever receiveth a righteous man, in the name of a righteous man, shall receive a righteous man's reward," as the Lord has said.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:28
verses.text: Such is the favour in which hospitality stands with God, that not even the draught of cold water shall fail of getting a reward.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:29
verses.text: Thou seest that Abraham, in looking for guests, received God Himself to entertain.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:30
verses.text: Thou seest that Lot received the angels.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:31
verses.text: And how dost thou know that when thou receivest men, thou dost not receive Christ? Christ may be in the stranger that comes, for Christ is there in the person of the poor, as He Himself says: "I was in prison and thou camest to Me, I was naked and thou didst clothe Me".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:32
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:33
verses.text: It is sweet, then, to seek not for money but for grace.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:34
verses.text: It is true that this evil has long ago entered into human hearts, so that money stands in the place of honour, and the minds of men are filled with admiration for wealth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:35
verses.text: Thus love of money sinks in and as it were dries up every kindly duty; so that men consider everything a loss which is spent beyond the usual amount.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:36
verses.text: But even here the holy Scriptures have been on the watch against love of money, that it might prove no cause of hindrance, saying: "Better is hospitality, even though it consisteth only of herbs".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:37
verses.text: And again: "Better is bread in pleasantness with peace".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:38
verses.text: For the Scriptures teach us not to be wasteful, but liberal.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:39
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:40
verses.text: There are two kinds of free-giving, one arising from liberality, the other from wasteful extravagance.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:41
verses.text: It is a mark of liberality to receive the stranger, to clothe the naked, to redeem the captives, to help the needy.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:42
verses.text: It is wasteful to spend money on expensive banquets and much wine.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:43
verses.text: Wherefore one reads: "Wine is wasteful, drunkenness is abusive".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:44
verses.text: It is wasteful to spend one's own wealth merely for the sake of gaining the favour of the people.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:45
verses.text: This they do who spend their inheritance on the games of the circus, or on theatrical pieces and gladiatorial shows, or even a combat of wild beasts, just to surpass the fame of their forefathers for these things.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:46
verses.text: All this that they do is but foolish, for it is not right to be extravagant in spending money even on good works.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:47
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:48
verses.text: It is a right kind of liberality to keep due measure towards the poor themselves, that one may have enough for more; and not to go beyond the right limit for the sake of winning favour.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:49
verses.text: Whatever comes forth out of a pure sincere disposition, that is seemly.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:50
verses.text: It is also seemly not to enter on unnecessary undertakings, nor to omit those that are needed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:51
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:52
verses.text: But it befits the priest especially to adorn the temple of God with fitting splendour, so that the court of the Lord may be made glorious by his endeavours.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:53
verses.text: He ought always to spend money as mercy demands.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:54
verses.text: It behoves him to give to strangers what is right.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:55
verses.text: This must not be too much, but enough; not more than, but as much as, kindly feeling demands, so that he may never seek another's favour at the expense of the poor, nor show himself as either too stingy or too free to the clergy.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:56
verses.text: The one act is unkind, the other wasteful.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:57
verses.text: It is unkind if money should be wanting for the necessities of those whom one ought to win back from their wretched employments.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 21:58
verses.text: It is wasteful if there should be too much over for pleasure.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 22

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 22:1
verses.text: Chapter XXII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 22:2
verses.text: We must observe a right standard between too great mildness and excessive harshness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 22:3
verses.text: They who endeavour to creep into the hearts of others by a false show of mildness gain nothing substantial or lasting.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 22:4
verses.text: This the example of Absalom plainly enough shows.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 22:5
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 22:6
verses.text: Moreover, due measure befits even our words and instructions, that it may not seem as though there was either too great mildness or too much harshness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 22:7
verses.text: Many prefer to be too mild, so as to appear to be good.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 22:8
verses.text: But it is certain that nothing feigned or false can bear the form of true virtue; nay, it cannot even last.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 22:9
verses.text: At first it flourishes, then, as time goes on, like a floweret it fades and passes away, but what is true and sincere has a deep root.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 22:10
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 22:11
verses.text: To prove by examples our assertion that what is feigned cannot last, but flourishing just for a time quickly fails, we will take one example of pretence and falsehood from that family, from which we have already drawn so many examples to show their growth in virtue.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 22:12
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 22:13
verses.text: Absalom was King David's son, known for his beauty, of splendid appearance and in the heyday of youth; so that no other such man as he was found in Israel.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 22:14
verses.text: He was without a blemish from the sole of his foot to the crown of his head.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 22:15
verses.text: He had for himself a chariot and horses and fifty men to run before him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 22:16
verses.text: He rose at early dawn and stood before the gate in the way, and whoever he knew to be seeking the judgment of the king, he called to himself, saying: "From what city art thou?" And he answered: "I thy servant am of one of the tribes of Israel".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 22:17
verses.text: And Absalom answered: "Thy words are good and right.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 22:18
verses.text: Is there none given thee by the king to hear thee? Who will make me a judge? And whosoever will come unto me, that hath need of judgment, I will give him justice".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 22:19
verses.text: With such words he cajoled them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 22:20
verses.text: And when they came to make obeisance to him, stretching forth his hand he took hold of them and kissed them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 22:21
verses.text: So he turned the hearts of all to himself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 22:22
verses.text: For flattery of this sort quickly finds its way to touch the very depths of the heart.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 22:23
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 22:24
verses.text: Those spoilt and ambitious men chose what for a time seemed an honour to them, and was pleasing and enjoyable.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 22:25
verses.text: But whilst that delay took place, which the prophet, being prudent above all, thought ought to intervene, they could no longer hold out or bear it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 22:26
verses.text: Then David having no doubt about the victory commended his son to those who went out to fight, so that they should spare him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 22:27
verses.text: He would not engage in the battle himself lest he should seem to be taking up arms against one who was still his son, though attempting to destroy his father.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 22:28
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 22:29
verses.text: It is clear, then, that those things are lasting and sound, which are true and grow out of a sincere and not a false heart.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 22:30
verses.text: Those, however, which are brought about by pretence and adulation can never last for long.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 23

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 23:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 23:2
verses.text: The good faith of those who are easily bought over with money or flattery is a frail thing to trust to.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 23:3
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 23:4
verses.text: Who would suppose that those who are bought over to obedience by money, or those who are allured by adulation, would ever be faithful to them? For the former are ever ready to sell themselves, whilst the latter cannot put up with a hard rule.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 23:5
verses.text: They are easily won with a little adulation, but if one reproves them by a word, they murmur against it, they give one up, they go away with hostile feelings, they forsake one in anger.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 23:6
verses.text: They prefer to rule rather than to obey.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 23:7
verses.text: They think that those whom they ought to have placed over them ought to be subject to themselves, as though indebted to them by their kindness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 23:8
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 23:9
verses.text: What man is there that thinks those will be faithful to himself, whom he believes he will have to bind to himself by money or flattery? For he who takes thy money supposes that he is cheaply held, and looked down upon, unless the money is paid again and again.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 23:10
verses.text: So he frequently expects his price; whilst the other, who is met with prayer and flattery, is always wanting to be asked.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 24

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 24:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIV.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 24:2
verses.text: We must strive for preferment only by right means.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 24:3
verses.text: An office undertaken must be carried out wisely and with moderation.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 24:4
verses.text: The inferior clergy should not detract from the bishop's reputation by feigned virtues; nor again, should the bishop be jealous of a cleric, but he should be just in all things and especially in giving judgment.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 24:5
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 24:6
verses.text: I think, then, that one should strive to win preferment, especially in the Church, only by good actions and with a right aim; so that there may be no proud conceit, no idle carelessness, no shameful disposition of mind, no unseemly ambition.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 24:7
verses.text: A plain simplicity of mind is enough for everything, and commends itself quite sufficiently.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 24:8
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 24:9
verses.text: When in office, again, it is not right to be harsh and severe, nor may one be too easy; lest on the one hand we should seem to be exercising a despotic power, and on the other to be by no means filling the office we had taken up.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 24:10
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 24:11
verses.text: We must strive also to win many by kindnesses and duties that we can do, and to preserve the favour already shown us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 24:12
verses.text: For they will with good reason forget the  benefits of former times if they are now vexed at some great wrong.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 24:13
verses.text: For it often enough happens that those one has shown favour to and allowed to rise step by step, are driven away, if one decides in some unworthy way to put another before them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 24:14
verses.text: But it is seemly for a priest to show such favour in his kindnesses and his decisions as to guard equity, and to show regard to the other clergy as to parents.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 24:15
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 24:16
verses.text: Those who once stood approved should not now become overbearing, but rather, as mindful of the grace they have received, stand firm in their humility.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 24:17
verses.text: A priest ought not to be offended if either cleric or attendant or any ecclesiastic should win regard for himself, by showing mercy, or by fasting, or by uprightness of life, or by teaching and reading.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 24:18
verses.text: For the grace of the Church is the praise of the teacher.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 24:19
verses.text: It is a good thing that the work of another should be praised, if only it be done without any desire to boast.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 24:20
verses.text: For each one should receive praise from the lips of his neighbour, and not from his own mouth, and each one should be commended by the work he has done, not merely by the wishes he had.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 24:21
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 24:22
verses.text: But if any one is disobedient to his bishop and wishes to exalt and upraise himself, and to overshadow his bishop's merits by a feigned appearance of learning or humility or mercy, he is wandering from the truth in his pride; for the rule of truth is, to do nothing to advance one's own cause whereby another loses ground, nor to use whatever good one has to the disgrace or blame of another.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 24:23
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 24:24
verses.text: Never protect a wicked man, nor allow the sacred things to be given over to an unworthy one; on the other hand, do not harass and press hard on a man whose fault is not clearly proved.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 24:25
verses.text: Injustice quickly gives offence in every case, but especially in the Church, where equity ought to exist, where like treatment should be given to all, so that a powerful person may not claim the more, nor a rich man appropriate the more.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 24:26
verses.text: For whether we be poor or rich, we are one in Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 24:27
verses.text: Let him that lives a holier life claim nothing more thereby for himself; for he ought rather to be the more humble for it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 24:28
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 24:29
verses.text: In giving judgment let us have no respect of persons.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 24:30
verses.text: Favour must be put out of sight, and the case be decided on its merits.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 24:31
verses.text: Nothing is so great a strain on another's good opinion or confidence, as the fact of our giving away the cause of the weaker to the more powerful in any case that comes before us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 24:32
verses.text: The same happens if we are hard on the poor, whilst we make excuses for the rich man when guilty.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 24:33
verses.text: Men are ready enough to flatter those in high positions, so as not to let them think themselves injured, or to feel vexed as though overthrown.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 24:34
verses.text: But if thou fearest to give offence then do not undertake to give judgment.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 24:35
verses.text: If thou art a priest or some cleric do not urge it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 24:36
verses.text: It is allowable for thee to be silent in the matter, if it be a money affair, though it is always due to consistency to be on the side of equity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 24:37
verses.text: But in the cause of God, where there is danger to the whole Church, it is no small sin to act as though one saw nothing.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 25

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 25:1
verses.text: Chapter XXV.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 25:2
verses.text: Benefits should be conferred on the poor rather than on the rich, for these latter either think a return is expected from them, or else they are angry at seeming to be indebted for such an action.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 25:3
verses.text: But the poor man makes God the debtor in his place, and freely owns to the benefits he has received.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 25:4
verses.text: To these remarks is added a warning to despise riches.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 25:5
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 25:6
verses.text: But what advantage is it to thee to show favour to a rich man? Is it that he is more ready to repay one who loves him? For we generally show favour to those from whom we expect to receive a return of favour.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 25:7
verses.text: But we ought to think far more of the weak and helpless, because we hope to receive, on behalf of him who has it not, a recompense from the Lord Jesus, Who in the likeness of a marriage feast has given us a general representation of virtue.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 25:8
verses.text: By this He bids us confer benefits rather on those who cannot give them to us in return, teaching us to bid to our feasts and meals, not those who are rich, but those that are poor.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 25:9
verses.text: For the rich seem to be asked that they may prepare a banquet for us in return; the poor, as they have nothing wherewith to make return, when they receive anything, make the Lord to be our recompense Who has offered Himself as surety for the poor.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 25:10
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 25:11
verses.text: In the ordinary course of things, too, the conferring of a benefit on the poor is of more use than when it is conferred on the rich.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 25:12
verses.text: The rich man scorns the benefit and is ashamed to feel indebted for a favour.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 25:13
verses.text: Nay, moreover, whatever is offered to him he takes as due to his merits, as though only a just debt were paid him; or else he thinks it was but given because the giver expected a still greater return to be made him by the rich man.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 25:14
verses.text: So, in accepting a kindness, the  rich man, on that very ground, thinks that he has given more than he ever received.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 25:15
verses.text: The poor man, however, though he has no money wherewith he can repay, at least shows his gratitude.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 25:16
verses.text: And herein it is certain that he returns more than he received.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 25:17
verses.text: For money is paid in coins, but gratitude never fails; money grows less by payment, but gratitude fails when held back, and is preserved when given to others.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 25:18
verses.text: Nexta thing the rich man avoidsthe poor man owns that he feels bound by the debt.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 25:19
verses.text: He really thinks help has been given him, not that it has been offered in return for his honour.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 25:20
verses.text: He considers that his children have been again given him, that his life is restored and his family preserved.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 25:21
verses.text: How much better, then, is it to confer benefits upon the good than on the ungrateful.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 25:22
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 25:23
verses.text: Wherefore the Lord said to His disciples: "Take neither gold nor silver nor money".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 25:24
verses.text: Whereby as with a sickle He cuts off the love of money that is ever growing up in human hearts.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 25:25
verses.text: Peter also said to the lame man, who was always carried even from his mother's womb: "Silver and gold have I none, but what I have give I thee.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 25:26
verses.text: In the Name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth, arise and walk".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 25:27
verses.text: So he gave not money, but he gave health.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 25:28
verses.text: How much better it is to have health without money, than money without health! The lame man rose; he had not hoped for that: he received no money; though he had hoped for that.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 25:29
verses.text: But riches are hardly to be found among the saints of the Lord, so as to become objects of contempt to them.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 26

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 26:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVI.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 26:2
verses.text: How long standing an evil love of money is, is plain from many examples in the Old Testament.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 26:3
verses.text: And yet it is plain, too, how idle a thing the possession of money is.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 26:4
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 26:5
verses.text: But man's habits have so long applied themselves to this admiration of money, that no one is thought worthy of honour unless he is rich.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 26:6
verses.text: This is no new habit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 26:7
verses.text: Nay, this vice (and that makes the matter worse) grew long years ago in the hearts of men.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 26:8
verses.text: When the city of Jericho fell at the sound of the priests' trumpets, and Joshua the son of Nun gained the victory, he knew that the valour of the people was weakened through love of money and desire for gold.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 26:9
verses.text: For when Achan had taken a garment of gold and two hundred shekels of silver and a golden ingot from the spoils of the ruined city, he was brought before the Lord, and could not deny the theft, but owned it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 26:10
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 26:11
verses.text: Love of money, then, is an old, an ancient vice, which showed itself even at the declaration of the divine law; for a law was given to check it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 26:12
verses.text: On account of love of money Balak thought Balaam could be tempted by rewards to curse the people of our fathers.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 26:13
verses.text: Love of money would have won the day too, had not God bidden him hold back from cursing.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 26:14
verses.text: Overcome by love of money Achan led to destruction all the people of the fathers.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 26:15
verses.text: So Joshua the son of Nun, who could stay the sun from setting, could not stay the love of money in man from creeping on.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 26:16
verses.text: At the sound of his voice the sun stood still, but love of money stayed not.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 26:17
verses.text: When the sun stood still Joshua completed his triumph, but when love of money went on, he almost lost the victory.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 26:18
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 26:19
verses.text: Why? Did not the woman Delilah's love of money deceive Samson, the bravest man of all? So he who had torn asunder the roaring lion with his hands; who, when bound and handed over to his enemies, alone, without help, burst his bonds and slew a thousand of them; who broke the cords interwoven with sinews as though they were but the slight threads of a net; he, I say, having laid his head on the woman's knee, was robbed of the decoration of his victory-bringing hair, that which gave him his might.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 26:20
verses.text: Money flowed into the lap of the woman, and the favour of God forsook the man.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 26:21
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 26:22
verses.text: Love of money, then, is deadly.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 26:23
verses.text: Seductive is money, whilst it also defiles those who have it, and helps not those who have it not.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 26:24
verses.text: Supposing that money sometimes is a help, yet it is only a help to a poor man who makes his want known.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 26:25
verses.text: What good is it to him who does not long for it, nor seek it; who does not need its help and is not turned aside by pursuit of it? What good is it to others, if he who has it is alone the richer for it? Is he therefore more honourable because he has that whereby honour is often lost, because he has what he must guard rather than possess? We possess what we use, but what is beyond our use brings us no fruit of possession, but only the danger of watching.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 27

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 27:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 27:2
verses.text: In contempt of money there is the pattern of justice, which virtue bishops and clerics ought to aim at together with some others.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 27:3
verses.text: A few words are added on the duty of not bringing an excommunication too quickly into force.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 27:4
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 27:5
verses.text: To come to an end; we know that contempt of riches is a form of justice, therefore we ought to avoid love of money, and strive with all our powers never to do anything against justice, but to guard it in all our deeds and actions.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 27:6
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 27:7
verses.text: If we would please God, we must have love, we must be of one mind, we must follow humility, each one thinking the other higher than himself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 27:8
verses.text: This is true humility, when one never claims anything proudly for oneself, but thinks oneself to be the inferior.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 27:9
verses.text: The bishop should treat the clerics and attendants, who are indeed his sons, as members of himself, and give to each one that duty for which he sees him to be fit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 27:10
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 27:11
verses.text: Not without pain is a limb of the body cut off which has become corrupt.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 27:12
verses.text: It is treated for a long time, to see if it can be cured with various remedies.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 27:13
verses.text: If it cannot be cured, then it is cut off by a good physician.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 27:14
verses.text: Thus it is a good bishop's desire to wish to heal the weak, to remove the spreading ulcers, to burn some parts and not to cut them off; and lastly, when they cannot be healed, to cut them off with pain to himself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 27:15
verses.text: Wherefore that beautiful rule of the Apostle stands forth brightly, that we should look each one, not on his own things, but on the things of others.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 27:16
verses.text: In this way it will never come about that we shall in anger give way to our own feelings, or concede more than is right in favour to our own wishes.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVIII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:2
verses.text: Mercy must be freely shown even though it brings an odium of its own.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:3
verses.text: With regard to this, reference is made to the well-known story about the sacred vessels which were broken up by Ambrose to pay for the redemption of captives; and very beautiful advice is given about the right use of the gold and silver which the Church possesses.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:4
verses.text: Next, after showing from the action of holy Lawrence what are the true treasures of the Church, certain rules are laid down which ought to be observed in melting down and employing for such uses the consecrated vessels of the Church.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:5
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:6
verses.text: It is a very great incentive to mercy to share in others' misfortunes, to help the needs of others as far as our means allow, and sometimes even beyond them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:7
verses.text: For it is better for mercy's sake to take up a case, or to suffer odium rather than to show hard feeling.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:8
verses.text: So I once brought odium on myself because I broke up the sacred vessels to redeem captivesa fact that could displease the Arians.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:9
verses.text: Not that it displeased them as an act, but as being a thing in which they could take hold of something for which to blame me.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:10
verses.text: Who can be so hard, cruel, iron-hearted, as to be displeased because a man is redeemed from death, or a woman from barbarian impurities, things that are worse than death, or boys and girls and infants from the pollution of idols, whereby through fear of death they were defiled?  137.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:11
verses.text: Although we did not act thus without good reason, yet we have followed it up among the people so as to confess and to add again and again that it was far better to preserve souls than gold for the Lord.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:12
verses.text: For He Who sent the apostles without gold also brought together the churches without gold.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:13
verses.text: The Church has gold, not to store up, but to lay out, and to spend on those who need.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:14
verses.text: What necessity is there to guard what is of no good? Do we not know how much gold and silver the Assyrians took out of the temple of the Lord? Is it not much better that the priests should melt it down for the sustenance of the poor, if other supplies fail, than that a sacrilegious enemy should carry it off and defile it? Would not the Lord Himself say: Why didst thou suffer so many needy to die of hunger? Surely thou hadst gold? Thou shouldst have given them sustenance.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:15
verses.text: Why are so many captives brought on the slave market, and why are so many unredeemed left to be slain by the enemy? It had been better to preserve living vessels than gold ones.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:16
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:17
verses.text: To this no answer could be given.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:18
verses.text: For what wouldst thou say: I feared that the temple of God would need its ornaments? He would answer: The sacraments need not gold, nor are they proper to gold onlyfor they are not bought with gold.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:19
verses.text: The glory of the sacraments is the redemption of captives.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:20
verses.text: Truly they are precious vessels, for they redeem men from death.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:21
verses.text: That, indeed, is the true treasure of the Lord which effects what His blood effected.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:22
verses.text: Then, indeed, is the vessel of the Lord's blood recognized, when one sees in either redemption, so that the chalice redeems from the enemy those whom His blood redeemed from sin.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:23
verses.text: How beautifully it is said, when long lines of captives are redeemed by the Church: These Christ has redeemed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:24
verses.text: Behold the gold that can be tried, behold the useful gold, behold the gold of Christ which frees from death, behold the gold whereby modesty is redeemed and chastity is preserved.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:25
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:26
verses.text: These, then, I preferred to hand over to you as free men, rather than to store up the gold.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:27
verses.text: This crowd of captives, this company surely is more glorious than the sight of cups.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:28
verses.text: The gold of the Redeemer ought to contribute to this work so as to redeem those in danger.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:29
verses.text: I recognize the fact that the blood of Christ not only glows in cups of gold, but also by the office of redemption has impressed upon them the power of the divine operation.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:30
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:31
verses.text: Such gold the holy martyr Lawrence preserved for the Lord.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:32
verses.text: For when the treasures of the Church were demanded from him, he promised that he would show them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:33
verses.text: On the following day he brought the poor together.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:34
verses.text: When asked where the treasures were which he had promised, he pointed to the poor, saying: "These are the treasures of the Church".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:35
verses.text: And truly they were treasures, in whom Christ lives, in whom there is faith in Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:36
verses.text: So, too, the Apostle says: "We have this treasure in earthen vessels".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:37
verses.text: What greater treasures has Christ than those in whom He says He Himself lives? For thus it is written: "I was hungry and ye gave Me to eat, I was thirsty and ye gave Me to drink, I was a stranger and ye took Me in".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:38
verses.text: And again: "What thou didst to one of these, thou didst it unto Me".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:39
verses.text: What better treasures has Jesus than those in which He loves to be seen?  141.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:40
verses.text: These treasures Lawrence pointed out, and prevailed, for the persecutors could not take them away.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:41
verses.text: Jehoiachim, who preserved his gold during the siege and spent it not in providing food, saw his gold carried off, and himself led into captivity.
