verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:42
verses.text: Lawrence, who preferred to spend the gold of the Church on the poor, rather than to keep it in hand for the persecutor, received the sacred crown of martyrdom for the unique and deep-sighted vigour of his meaning.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:43
verses.text: Or was it perhaps said to holy Lawrence: "Thou shouldst not spend the treasures of the Church, or sell the sacred vessels"?  142.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:44
verses.text: It is necessary that every one should fill this office, with genuine good faith and clear-sighted forethought.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:45
verses.text: If any one derives profit from it for himself it is a crime, but if he spends the treasures on the poor, or redeems captives, he shows mercy.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:46
verses.text: For no one can say: Why does the poor man live? None can complain that captives are redeemed, none can find fault because a temple of the Lord is built, none can be angry because a plot of ground has been enlarged for the burial of the bodies of the faithful, none can be vexed because in the tombs of the Christians there is rest for the dead.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:47
verses.text: In these three ways it is allowable to break up, melt down, or sell even the sacred vessels of the Church.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:48
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:49
verses.text: It is necessary to see that the mystic cup does not go out of the Church, lest the service of the sacred chalice should be turned over to base uses.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:50
verses.text: Therefore vessels were first sought for in the Church which had not been consecrated to such holy uses.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:51
verses.text: Then broken up and afterwards melted down, they were given to the poor in small payments, and were also used for the ransom of captives.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 28:52
verses.text: But if new vessels fail, or those which never seem to have been used for such a holy purpose, then, as I have already said, I think that all might be put to this use without irreverence.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIX.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:2
verses.text: The property of widows or of all the faithful, that has been entrusted to the Church, ought to be defended though it brings danger to oneself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:3
verses.text: This is illustrated by the example of Onias the priest, and of Ambrose, bishop of Ticinum.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:4
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:5
verses.text: Great care must be taken that the property entrusted by widows remains inviolate.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:6
verses.text: It should be guarded without causing complaint, not only if it belongs to widows, but to any one at all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:7
verses.text: For good faith must be shown to all, though the cause of the widow and orphans comes first.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:8
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:9
verses.text: So everything entrusted to the temple was preserved in the name of the widows alone, as we read in the book of the Maccabees.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:10
verses.text: For when information was given of the money, which Simon treacherously had told King Antiochus could be found in large quantities in the temple at Jerusalem, Heliodorus was sent to look into the matter.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:11
verses.text: He came to the temple, and made known to the high priest his hateful information and the reason of his coming.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:12
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:13
verses.text: Then the priest said that only means for the maintenance of the widows and orphans was laid up there.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:14
verses.text: And when Heliodorus would have gone to seize it, and to claim it on the king's behalf, the, priests cast themselves before the altar, after putting on their priestly robes, and with tears called on the living God Who had given them the law concerning trust-money to show Himself as guardian of His own commands.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:15
verses.text: The changed look and colour of the high priest showed what grief of soul and anxiety and tension of mind were his.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:16
verses.text: All wept, for the spot would fall into contempt, if not even in the temple of God safe and faithful guardianship could be preserved.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:17
verses.text: Women with breasts girded, and virgins who usually were shut in, knocked at the doors.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:18
verses.text: Some ran to the walls, others looked out of the windows, all raised their hands to heaven in prayer that God would stand by His laws.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:19
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:20
verses.text: But Heliodorus, undeterred by this, was eager to carry out his intention, and had already surrounded the treasury with his followers, when suddenly there appeared to him a dreadful horseman all glorious in golden armour, his horse also being adorned with costly ornaments.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:21
verses.text: Two other youths also appeared in glorious might and wondrous beauty, in splendour and glory and beauteous array.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:22
verses.text: They stood round him, and on either side beat the sacrilegious wretch, and gave him stroke after stroke without intermission.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:23
verses.text: What more need I say? Shut in by darkness he fell to the ground, and lay there nearly dead with fear at this plain proof of divine power, nor had he any hope of safety left within him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:24
verses.text: Joy returned to those who were in fear, fear fell on those who were so proud before.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:25
verses.text: And some of the friends of Heliodorus in their trouble besought Onias, asking life for him, since he was almost at his last breath.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:26
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:27
verses.text: When, therefore, the high priest asked for this, the same youths again appeared to Heliodorus, clad in the same garments, and said to him: Give thanks to Onias the high priest, for whose sake thy life is granted thee.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:28
verses.text: But do thou, having experienced the scourge of God, go and tell thy friends how much thou hast learnt of the sanctity of the temple and the power of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:29
verses.text: With these words they passed out of sight.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:30
verses.text: Heliodorus then, his life having come back to him, offered a sacrifice to the Lord, gave thanks to the priest Onias, and returned with his army to the king, saying: "If thou hast an enemy or one who is plotting against thy power, send him thither and thou wilt receive him back well scourged".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:31
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:32
verses.text: Therefore, my sons, good faith must be preserved in the case of trust-money, and care, too, must be shown.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:33
verses.text: Your service will glow the brighter if the oppression of a powerful man, which some widow or orphan cannot withstand, is checked by the assistance of the Church, and if ye show that the command of the Lord has more weight with you than the favour of the rich.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:34
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:35
verses.text: Ye also remember how often we entered on a contest against the royal attacks, on behalf of the trust-money belonging to widows, yea, and to others as well.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:36
verses.text: You and I shared this in common.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:37
verses.text: I will also mention the late case of the Church at Ticinum, which was in danger of losing the widow's trust-money that it had received.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:38
verses.text: For when he who wanted to claim it on some imperial rescript demanded it, the clergy did not maintain their rights.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:39
verses.text: For they themselves, having once been called to office and sent to intervene, now supposed that they could not oppose the emperor's orders.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:40
verses.text: The plain words of the rescript were read, the orders of the chief officer of the court were there, he who was to act in the matter was at hand.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:41
verses.text: What more was to be said? It was handed over.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:42
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:43
verses.text: However, after taking counsel with me, the holy bishop took possession of the rooms to which he knew that the widow's property had been carried.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:44
verses.text: As it could not be carried away, it was all set down in writing.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:45
verses.text: Later on it was again demanded on proof of the document.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:46
verses.text: The emperor repeated the order, and would meet us himself in his own person.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:47
verses.text: We refused.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:48
verses.text: And when the force of the divine law, and a long list of passages and the danger of Heliodorus was explained, at length the emperor became reasonable.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:49
verses.text: Afterwards, again, an attempt was made to seize it, but the good bishop anticipated the attempt and restored to the widow all he had received.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 29:50
verses.text: So faith was preserved, but the oppression was no longer a cause for fear; for now it is the matter itself, not good faith, that is in danger.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 30

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 30:1
verses.text: Chapter XXX.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 30:2
verses.text: The ending of the book brings an exhortation to avoid ill-will, and to seek prudence, faith, and the other virtues.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 30:3
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 30:4
verses.text: My sons, avoid wicked men, guard against the envious.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 30:5
verses.text: There is this difference between a wicked and an envious man: the wicked man is delighted at his own good fortune, but the envious is tortured at the  thought of another's.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 30:6
verses.text: The former loves evil, the latter hates good.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 30:7
verses.text: So he is almost more bearable who desires good for himself alone, than he who desires evil for all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 30:8
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 30:9
verses.text: My sons, think before you act, and when you have thought long then do what you consider right.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 30:10
verses.text: When the opportunity of a praiseworthy death is given let it be seized at once.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 30:11
verses.text: Glory that is put off flies away and is not easily laid hold of again.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 30:12
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 30:13
verses.text: Love faith.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 30:14
verses.text: For by his devotion and faith Josiah won great love for himself from his enemies.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 30:15
verses.text: For he celebrated the Lord's passover when he was eighteen years old, as no one had done it before him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 30:16
verses.text: As then in zeal he was superior to those who went before him, so do ye, my sons, show zeal for God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 30:17
verses.text: Let zeal for God search you through, and devour you, so that each one of you may say: "The zeal of thine house hath eaten me up.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 30:18
verses.text: " An apostle of Christ was called the zealot.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 30:19
verses.text: But why do I speak of an apostle? The Lord Himself said: "The zeal of thine house hath eaten Me up".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 30:20
verses.text: Let it then be real zeal for God, not mean earthy zeal, for that causes jealousy.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 30:21
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 30:22
verses.text: Let there be peace among you, which passeth all understanding.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 30:23
verses.text: Love one another.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 30:24
verses.text: Nothing is sweeter than charity, nothing more blessed than peace.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 30:25
verses.text: Ye yourselves know that I have ever loved you and do now love you above all others.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 30:26
verses.text: As the children of one father ye have become united under the bond of brotherly affection.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 30:27
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book II 30:28
verses.text: Whatsoever is good, that hold fast; and the God of peace and love be with you in the Lord Jesus, to Whom be honour and glory, dominion and might, together with the Holy Spirit, for ever and ever, Amen.
